the beauty of this recipe
is you can pretty much make

It's so easy, fresh, and
seriously so much better
than something out of the store.

First thing's first, we're
gonna make the pastry cream.
It's so easy, but you wanna make it first

because it needs a little time
to set in the refrigerator.
In a medium heatproof mixing bowl,

combine one egg, two
yolks, half a cup of sugar,
three tablespoons of cornstarch,

and an eighth of a
teaspoon of fine sea salt.

Whisk that together until
it's completely smooth
and lightened in color.
It takes about two minutes.

Next, in a large saucepan,
add two cups of whole milk
and two tablespoons of unsalted butter.

Set your saucepan over medium
heat and stir occasionally

to prevent the milk from
scalding or forming a film.

As soon as you see it start
to boil, take it off the heat.
This next part is super important.
You have to temper the eggs
so you don't end up with scrambled eggs.
While whisking constantly,

slowly add one third of
that hot milk mixture.
Now you can pour that warm egg mixture

back into the saucepan
with the remaining milk
and whisk to combine.
Set that over medium heat
and whisk constantly until it's thickened.
This takes about two to three minutes.
You also wanna give it a chance
to cook off some of that cornstarch
so the cream doesn't separate.

Stop mixing for a few seconds
and watch for bubbling.
Once you see the bubbling,

reduce the heat to a very low
boil and continue cooking,
stirring constantly for another minute.
When it's done,

the cream should be
thickened, smooth, and glossy.

Take it off the heat and
whisk in your vanilla extract.
Transfer your custard to a shallow bowl

and cover that immediately
with a layer of plastic wrap.
Make sure to lay the plastic wrap

directly over the
surface of the hot cream.
This prevents a film from forming on top.

Let that cool completely
to room temperature,
then refrigerate for at least two hours.

Or you can refrigerate
up to three days ahead.

Now we're gonna make the
easy sweet tart crust.
In the bowl of a stand mixer
fitted with a paddle attachment,

combine 10 tablespoons of
unsalted softened butter,

one third cup of sugar, and
a quarter teaspoon of salt.
Cream that together on medium speed

just until it's combined
for about two minutes,
scraping down the bowl as needed.

Now add one egg yolk,
which tenderizes the dough,

and one teaspoon of a
real vanilla extract.

And I'm using my homemade
two ingredient extract.
I will link to the recipe in the notes.
Beat together just until incorporated
and scrape down the bowl as needed.

Now add one and a half
cups of all purpose flour.
And if you haven't already,

make sure you watch our video
on how to measure ingredients.
It will help you with all of your baking.

Once the flour is in, mix on
low speed for about a minute,
or until the flour is fully incorporated
and the dough comes together.
It should look like a cookie dough.
Shape the dough into a disc,
then set it into a 10 or 11 inch tart pan.
Press the dough into the tart pan

until it's about one
fourth inch thick all over
on the sides and bottom of the pan.
Continue working the dough
until you have an even layer all around.
I like using the bottom of a measuring cup
to press the corners in squarely.
Now, last but not least,
trim off the excess dough at the top.
I love using my food scraper for this.

It's one of my favorite,
most versatile kitchen tools,
and I will link to it in the notes.
But you can also use a butter knife.

Cover the dough with plastic
wrap and freeze for 30 minutes

while you preheat the oven
to 350 degrees Fahrenheit.
Set the tart pan over a baking sheet
to make it easier to transfer,

and bake at 350 degrees Fahrenheit
in the center of the oven
for about 25 to 28 minutes,
or until the crust is golden brown.
Then take it out of the oven
and set the tart pan over a wire rack

and let it cool completely
to room temperature
before removing the mold.

Now, I have some pastry cream
here that I made earlier

which has chilled and set
and is ready for filling.

Set your cooled tart crust
over a serving platter.

You can keep the bottom of
the tart pan under the crust,

or you can gently pry
it off if you prefer.

Give the pastry cream a
quick stir to lighten it up,
then you can add it to your crust.
Now smooth out the top

so you have an even
surface for your fruit.
What I love about fruit tarts

is you can use whatever
fruit is in season.

You'll need about four cups
of fresh fruit or berries.

Here's my favorite way
to decorate a fruit tart.
Working from the outside in,

I like to start with some
fresh sliced strawberries
around the border.
It also looks great when you pair
different color fruits next to each other.

After a couple of rows of raspberries,

it looks great to go in and
fill in the empty spaces.
It does take a few minutes
to decorate a fruit tart like this,
but if you're short on time

you can absolutely just
put in the fruit randomly

and your tart will still
look beautiful and delicious.
